251,Large City Air Quality Ranking,Annual Average PM 2.5,"

The 24-hour average concentrations of PM 2.5 for each regulatory monitor within a city are used to compute an annual average for each monitor. The city is assigned an annual average PM 2.5 concentration that is equal to the maximum average measured by any of the monitors. The maximum average for a particular year is then averaged with the previous and subsequent years (and is in reality a three-year rolling average). This computation is made for NYC and eight comparison cities with populations over 1,000,000 (Chicago, Dallas, Houston, Los Angeles, Philadelphia, Phoenix, San Antonio and San Diego)

",United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data

256,State of Good Repair,Bridges,"The NYC Department of Transportation (DOT) has under its purview 842 bridges. Federal and State law require that bridges be inspected a minimum of every two years. New York State performs the actual bridge inspections and assigns a numerical rating. The NYC DOT then translates those ratings to the verbal designations of ""very good,"" ""good,"" ""fair"" or ""poor."" This indicator is the percent of bridges rated as either ""very good"", ""good"", or ""fair"".",New York City Mayor's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) PlaNYC Indicator Data

257,State of Good Repair,Roads,"The NYC DOT Street Assessment Unit conducts an annual pavement condition survey that assesses conditions for one half of New York City streets. The entire city is evaluated once every two years. Street Assessment inspectors rate individual city streets on a scale of 1 through 10 (1 being the worst and 10 being the best). Any street that receives a rating of 7 or below is eligible for resurfacing, whereas any street with a rating of 8 through 10 is not eligible and is in a state of good repair. Reported are the percentages of streets rating between 8 and 10.",New York City Mayor's Office of Long Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) PlaNYC Indicator Data

258,State of Good Repair,Subway Station Components,"The number of subway stations for which infrastructure components are replaced on a schedule consistent with its life expectancy. The indicator tracks how many stations have been renovated by the end of their expected useful life, expressed as a percentage.","Metropolitan Transportation Authority "

260,Park Distance,New Yorkers within 1/4 Mile,"The percentage of the census block area that falls within 1/4 mile of a park edge in a given year, multiplied by the total population of the Census block, summed for all census blocks, then expressed as a percent of 2000 Census population. ",New York City Department of Parks and Recreation

261,Greenhouse Gas Emissions,Per Capita,"The number of metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emitted by NYC buildings (direct emissions from combustion of fuel oil and natural gas, indirect emissions from generation of electricity and steam)
column2: transportation (direct emissions from buses, commuter rail, trucks, and passenger cars, and indirect emissions from electricity for mass transit)
column3: and indirect emissions from generation of electricity used in streetlights and traffic signals
column4: together with fugitive and process emissions (from solid waste management, electricity distribution, wastewater treatment, and vehicle cooling). CO2 equivalent includes emissions of CO2 as well as an equivalent amount of CO2 (in terms of global warming impact) of other greenhouse gases, including methane, nitrous oxide, hydroflourocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride. Each gas is converted to CO2e, based on its potential to trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere, and emissions from all six gases are added together for reporting in one common unit.

265,"Housing Supply ",Total Number of Existing Units,"The number of housing units in NYC is derived from the Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS), which is a triennial, population-based, cross-sectional survey of housing units in NYC.",New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

266,Housing Affordability,Housing Affordable for Median Income NYC Household,"For each year of Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS) data, a housing budget is calculated by taking the estimated citywide median household income for all households (from the HVS), divided by 12 months, and multiplied by 0.3. The estimated percentage of rental units (occupied and vacant/available for rent) with an asking rent (contract) less than or equal to the derived maximum housing budget are counted as affordable to the typical NYC household. This measure incorporates changes in median household income as well as changes in asking rent. ",New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)
